awd_titl_txt: Geographic Patterns and Spatial Scales of Alpine Plant Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project analyzes the way in which spatial scale changes how local habitat, regional climate, and geographic separation affect plant community composition and diversity. According to basic theory in biogeography, the relative importance of the biological and environmental factors that affect species coexistence, and thus diversity, varies with spatial scale.  The research assesses the relative importance of the controlling factors as well as specific geographies of location within increasing spatial scales and among places that vary in isolation.  This change with scale and isolation is relevant to fundamental understanding of how diversity arises and is maintained, and this research helps guide interpretation of observations of current global change impacts.  For this project, the alpine tundra biome serves as a useful model system because its plant community composition varies across and within mountain ranges and regions.  Project results will be shared with other researchers working on such interpretation in global ecological monitoring programs, such as the Global Observation Research Initiative in Alpine Environments, as well as with the general public through outreach via the National Park Service's Crown of the Continent Learning Center.  The STEM workforce will be strengthened through the training of a postdoctoral researcher and undergraduates.

This research examines the role of spatial scale in plant community biogeography.  The investigator will assess the variation in plant community composition in alpine tundra in relation to three factors: local habitat (such as soils and topography), climate (biologically relevant seasonal variables), and geographic distance (a proxy for past dispersal).  Which of the three factors, with multiple variables for each, is most important to the patterns of diversity among plots within distances ranging from 100 meters to greater than 1000 kilometers, will be determined statistically.  The pattern of changes in their relative importance along a gradient of increasing distances will be analyzed.  Specifics of isolation will be evaluated through the inclusion of discontinuous ranges.  These analyses test the fundamental theory that the drivers change in a regular pattern as scale is increased.  The project increases knowledge of the importance of spatial interpretation in biogeographic theory and its applications.  The alpine tundra found in an arc across southern-to-eastern Europe, from Spain to Romania, will be studied because the species composition and environment has been recorded for thousands of plots with the same methodology.  Insights for biogeographic theory and applications will be relevant to other alpine regions, such as those of the western United States, as well as to other biomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to assess how the environmental factors that determine the structure and diversity of plant communities across regions vary with the spatial scale of the data and analyses. Understanding should help guide interpretation of observations of, and policy responses to, current climate change impacts. We used data from 16,000 plots of alpine grasslands of 23 mountain ranges in southern and central Europe.

By comparing the relative importance of the difference in the environment and geographic distance in explaining the similarities in the vegetation of the 23 ranges, we found that differences in climate were important when ranges were close, but distance per se was more important among pairs of ranges greater than 1500 km distant.

Scale was further examined in the context of the question of area versus environmental heterogeneity in the explanation of species diversity. In the alpine data from Europe, heterogeneity area was relatively more important, but area was still significant and more among the smaller mountain ranges. In simulation experiments this scale difference, which could be anticipated in the well-known Species-Area Relationship curve, was confirmed.

The data on the current extent of alpine habitat in the 23 ranges and the climates of the areas were used as a basis for assessing how much area would still be within the range of the current climate in climates projected for 2100. The worst-case scenario eliminated alpine habitat from all but the highest ranges of the Alps, but other scenarios maintained some alpine habitat on all but the smaller of the 23 ranges.

A very small side effort produced a commentary on definitions of alpine treeline in response to one that was misguided. Defining treeline is critical to delineating the extent of alpine habitat.

For outreach to the public, we created a map of the alpine habitats of the western USA; the map is for display, but the data could be used in further research. This map, in addition to highlighting a sensitive ecosystem, complement the maps from Europe used in the earlier parts of this project. The map and its description have been archived at Dryad and will be distributed digitally and printed.

A key element of outreach was meeting with staff from the Crown of the Continent Research and Learning Center and additional National Park Service resource managers and researchers at Glacier National Park. We reviewed ideas and drafts of material for public outreach that they could disseminate. Working with their science communication specialist, I created a draft Resource Brief that is now part of their public web presence.

For further outreach, I met with colleagues in Vienna. To create a basis for linking the work to their projects, I made a presentation to interested faculty and graduate students at the University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences. In a meeting on a second day, joined by colleagues from the University of Vienna and my primary colleague on the earlier work from the University of Oviedo, we discussed new work that would link our projects. This led to the development of a new simulation model to examine the old question of island biography - whether few larger or more smaller reserves, here applied to alpine microrefugia, conserve more biodiversity - and the importance of ease of movement across an alpine slope to track climate change in microhabitats. The model changed in its development and results were that the number of virtual species conserved had a bimodal response on a gradient of the buffering effect of microrefugia. The purpose of this effort is to create an avenue for the core work on this project to be more useful to their future research on microrefugia, and a draft paper on the model is now circulating among these coauthors.

Lastly, in another effort to link the research to alpine vegetation in the USA, I analyzed data from a previous NSF project and have written and submitted a paper on the variation in the importance of geomorphic forms in different climates.

In conclusion, the importance of the spatial pattern of the environmental template on which human-environment processes evolve, a longstanding question in biogeography, has been broadened by the examination of how it changes with spatial scale. This research has contributed to the foundational knowledge in this area by identifying the factors that maintain biodiversity at different scales and by showing how the roles of area and environmental heterogeneity change with scale. Applications of this knowledge were then developed to enhance the anticipation, interpretation, and mitigation of environmental consequences of climate change.
